text: <@U01RJ5W5ZED> has joined the channel

I've been exploring a single trigger for pre-off horse racing markets that I'm hoping to get some advice on. The strategy places a lay bet if the single trigger is met. Over 1800 markets the trigger returns a profit (beats fair value 56% of the time, and sum of lay bet prices is less than sum of fair value prices) if I look at a subset of all runners, but a loss if I look at all runners (warning sign?). Even though the trigger returns a profit, it is a significantly bumpy ride. I looked at the dose response in relation to the strength of the trigger, and there is a tiny positive correlation (size of trigger value/value found). Honestly, I think that the trigger may simply be skimming some noise before the market is particularly efficient because if it places bets only in the last hour before the off then it makes a loss, or may simply be overfit.
I tried to improve the consistency of the results by:
• encouraging the strategy to take similar total stakes across each runner bets are placed on
• increasing allowed selection exposure
• 'cashing out' bets that aren't value at the off (improved consistency but made the trigger produce a loss)
• only looking at bets in certain time periods
None of these things helped with consistency of results. I'm interested in what sort of things I should be thinking about to improve consistency of results (other than removing root causes of bad bets or a secondary trigger that confirms value), and whether the trigger itself appears worthless. I'd appreciate any advice anyone is willing to give, even if it's throw it all away and start again! Cheers

elements.text:
I've been exploring a single trigger for pre-off horse racing markets that I'm hoping to get some advice on. The strategy places a lay bet if the single trigger is met. Over 1800 markets the trigger returns a profit (beats fair value 56% of the time, and sum of lay bet prices is less than sum of fair value prices) if I look at a subset of all runners, but a loss if I look at all runners (warning sign?). Even though the trigger returns a profit, it is a significantly bumpy ride. I looked at the dose response in relation to the strength of the trigger, and there is a tiny positive correlation (size of trigger value/value found). Honestly, I think that the trigger may simply be skimming some noise before the market is particularly efficient because if it places bets only in the last hour before the off then it makes a loss, or may simply be overfit.
I tried to improve the consistency of the results by:
encouraging the strategy to take similar total stakes across each runner bets are placed on
increasing allowed selection exposure
'cashing out' bets that aren't value at the off (improved consistency but made the trigger produce a loss)
only looking at bets in certain time periods

None of these things helped with consistency of results. I'm interested in what sort of things I should be thinking about to improve consistency of results (other than removing root causes of bad bets or a secondary trigger that confirms value), and whether the trigger itself appears worthless. I'd appreciate any advice anyone is willing to give, even if it's throw it all away and start again! Cheers

text:
I'm in a very similar boat to <@U01LD279D16>. I have a preplay, straight laying strategy that lays at < BSP on >80% of bets, so shouldn't that _theoretically_ produce a profit long term? The other 20% are slightly >= BSP but only by small margins. There is an option to back at BSP to reduce volatility but that feels a bit dirty and I've not yet calculated if it would actually be +EV.
Also, what's the best way to calculate expected drawdown for a strategy?

produce a profit long term? The other 20% are slightly >= BSP but only by small margins. There is an option to back at BSP to reduce volatility but that feels a bit dirty and I've not yet calculated if it would actually be +EV.
Also, what's the best way to calculate expected drawdown for a strategy?

text: I meant equalising the stake of the back bet you've laid as far as possible. So, for example, if the strategy laid the base stake x3 on a single runner, when the chance arises to lay a different runner the strategy would take a bigger stake to try and even this up

text: Simple example, you placed a (real) £2 back bet at 2.04 and the BSP was 2. The bet lost. Realised return is -£2 but you had positive EV on this bet. This obviously scales up, realised return over a large number of bets could be poor but EV could be good, due to bad luck

text:
Taking prices with 3% margin against BSP is decent. Especially pre-off. It will be limited by how scalable it is. If it’s trading an hour before off time, then your backtests might be over optimistic because of market impact.  

You said the returns are bumpy. Is that because you are betting outright rather than closing? Why don’t you close at BSP (or at the off) for now and verify this trigger work in reality? Treat your open bets an hour before the race separately (give them their own strategy ref) to your closing bets, so that it’s easier to analyse them afterwards. 

If you’ve got 3% margin against BSP you’ll still make a healthy profit by closing (if the trigger pans out in live betting).

elements.text: Taking prices with 3% margin against BSP is decent. Especially pre-off. It will be limited by how scalable it is. If it’s trading an hour before off time, then your backtests might be over optimistic because of market impact.

You said the returns are bumpy. Is that because you are betting outright rather than closing? Why don’t you close at BSP (or at the off) for now and verify this trigger work in reality? Treat your open bets an hour before the race separately (give them their own strategy ref) to your closing bets, so that it’s easier to analyse them afterwards. 

If you’ve got 3% margin against BSP you’ll still make a healthy profit by closing (if the trigger pans out in live betting).

text: Oh, nice edit. :middle_finger: :smiley:

elements.text: Oh, nice edit.

text: :sunglasses:

At 3% margin on stakes, get £1000 in stake matched per race, that’s £30 per race on around 30 races a day. That’s £900 a day. 

Only bet outright if you have to, once you’re confident with the potential drawdowns. You might lose a bit from closing at BSP if you shift the price, but it shouldn’t be enough to kill a 3% margin. 

(Obvs trial with min stakes first and see how margin is impacted as stakes increase)

Only bet outright if you have to, once you’re confident with the potential drawdowns. You might lose a bit from closing at BSP if you shift the price, but it shouldn’t be enough to kill a 3% margin. 

(Obvs trial with min stakes first and see how margin is impacted as stakes increase)

text:
I think if you’re beating SP, but not comfortable with the outright betting, then just close at (estimated) BSP for now. Less stress, let’s you analyse live bets and how they would have done, there’s less comm. 

If after a while you see that your closing bets are consistently losing you money after months of doing this, then don’t close anymore!

elements.text: I think if you’re beating SP, but not comfortable with the outright betting, then just close at (estimated) BSP for now. Less stress, let’s you analyse live bets and how they would have done, there’s less comm.
If after a while you see that your closing bets are consistently losing you money after months of doing this, then don’t close anymore!

text: If the trigger is some kind of signal on a linear scale, then one would assume that larger the magnitude of the trigger, the higher it's EV. If you plot cumulative profit against this trigger value for the bets you've already taken, then it would show a somewhat exponential curve as the trigger value increases (gets stronger). If the curve is noisy then it would suggest your trigger can do with refining.

If the curve is noisy then it would suggest your trigger can do with refining.

text: Yes you are giving up value by hedging in this way but if you are concerned about volatility then it might be worth paying the price

text:
Yeah, it may be worth it for the reasons I gave above (less stress, can analyse live bets with less risk, less comm). 

I don’t think you need to be worrying about balancing liabilities across runners. I pretty much treat runners independently and have a max liability I’ll accept per runner. You should care more about getting value than balancing the books (that is, until you might consider hedging out pre-race start).

text:
Closing at BSP isn’t always a loser though. I have strategies which seem to do better when closing at BSP. Both my open and close seem to be +EV. I can only assume people follow similar signals to me, and by the time BSP arrives the price must be over bought or over sold and placing an opposite bet at BSP to close my position is a +EV bet. 

Once I take into account comm, it’s even more profitable to close (if it weren’t for premium charge).

Once I take into account comm, it’s even more profitable to close (if it weren’t for premium charge).

I’ve actually been wondering how I could just bet the BSP side of it. But given it’s simply calculated based on my current open position I’m not sure how I could. I suppose I could double close(?!) to stake more on BSP. Or I could “simulate” my position and close it.

Definitely a bit of a weird one. One of those cases where I’m not actually sure why I’m winning!

text: So if you’re backtesting as positive against BSP, I see no reason not to close at BSP for a while just to check how it does. You might be surprised. Maybe your open leg isn’t as +ve as you thought, maybe BSP turns out to be +ve, maybe it turns out to be -ve, but at least you can test it with little risk.

elements.text: So if you’re backtesting as positive against BSP, I see no reason not to close at BSP for a while just to check how it does. You might be surprised. Maybe your open leg isn’t as +ve as you thought, maybe BSP turns out to be +ve, maybe it turns out to be -ve, but at least you can test it with little risk.

text:
Of course the other issue is how to close at BSP without knowing what it will be. That’s more of an execution puzzle, and there’s several ways to do it. None of them will be perfect, but all of them should be close enough. So you’ll still end up with some open bet going into the race. 

Or you could close perfectly at the scheduled off. But then you’d be taking prices which causes extra slippage.

elements.text: Of course the other issue is how to close at BSP without knowing what it will be. That’s more of an execution puzzle, and there’s several ways to do it. None of them will be perfect, but all of them should be close enough. So you’ll still end up with some open bet going into the race.
Or you could close perfectly at the scheduled off. But then you’d be taking prices which causes extra slippage.

text: And don’t forget minimum stakes for BSP too. Can be a pain in bum when you’re wondering why one particular runner as a big liability remaining compared to everything else.

text: <@U01LD279D16> - I've just been reading the responses above to your question. you've received a tonne of excellent advice but there's one little thing in your question that's needling me that hasn't been addressed. You say that your strategy looks profitable _'if I look at a subset of all runners, but a loss if I look at all runners (warning sign?)'._ Well yeah - that might be a warning sign. I suppose the questions are; how is that subset generated, does it make sense and when did you think of it?

elements.text: - I've just been reading the responses above to your question. you've received a tonne of excellent advice but there's one little thing in your question that's needling me that hasn't been addressed. You say that your strategy looks profitable
'if I look at a subset of all runners, but a loss if I look at all runners (warning sign?)'.
Well yeah - that might be a warning sign. I suppose the questions are; how is that subset generated, does it make sense and when did you think of it?

text: Let's break that down, how is that subset generated and does it make sense? If it's something like: Loss on runners priced > 4, break even from 4 to 3, small profit from 3 to 2 and best profit < 2 then you're all good, but if it's 'handicaps only' then it's not going to be good news.

elements.text: Let's break that down, how is that subset generated and does it make sense? If it's something like: Loss on runners priced > 4, break even from 4 to 3, small profit from 3 to 2 and best profit < 2 then you're all good, but if it's 'handicaps only' then it's not going to be good news.

text: When did you think of it? Did you have it in mind when you started or did you find it by 'fishing' in your results? Ideally you start with an idea about how the market should work, work out what would prove that idea and then find the data to validate your hypothesis. If you do that you can usually be quite confident in your outcome because the probability of following that process and then getting a false positive outcome is quite slim. However If you found that your idea didn't work then fished around in the data until you found a subset that seemed good then your confidence should be much lower because the probability of finding a false positive moves towards 1 as you try more 'filters'.

elements.text: When did you think of it? Did you have it in mind when you started or did you find it by 'fishing' in your results? Ideally you start with an idea about how the market should work, work out what would prove that idea and then find the data to validate your hypothesis. If you do that you can usually be quite confident in your outcome because the probability of following that process and then getting a false positive outcome is quite slim. However If you found that your idea didn't work then fished around in the data until you found a subset that seemed good then your confidence should be much lower because the probability of finding a false positive moves towards 1 as you try more 'filters'.

text: However you test your data there's no substitute for standing back from both your strategy and your process and just asking whether it makes sense, whether you understand (or at least have an idea) where your value is coming from and whether your process was likely to lead to a false or real result.

elements.text: However you test your data there's no substitute for standing back from both your strategy and your process and just asking whether it makes sense, whether you understand (or at least have an idea) where your value is coming from and whether your process was likely to lead to a false or real result.

text: Thinking about it; we don't seem to talk much about evaluating your process but I think it's one of the best things you can do. _'Was what I've just done likely to produce a bullshit outcome'_ is a really important question that could either give confidence or raise your level of statistical vigilance.

elements.text: Thinking about it; we don't seem to talk much about evaluating your process but I think it's one of the best things you can do.
'Was what I've just done likely to produce a bullshit outcome'
is a really important question that could either give confidence or raise your level of statistical vigilance.

text: <@U01QZAZLNG6> has joined the channel
